mn19:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn19:3.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
mn19:4.1: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
mn19:4.2: ‘Why don’t I meditate by continually dividing my thoughts into two classes?’
mn19:4.3: So I assigned sensual, malicious, and cruel thoughts
mn19:4.5: And I assigned thoughts of renunciation, love, and kindness
mn19:5.1: Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a sensual thought arose.
mn19:5.3: ‘This sensual thought has arisen in me.
mn19:5.4: It leads to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both. It blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment.’
mn19:5.5: When I reflected that it leads to hurting myself, it went away.
mn19:5.6: When I reflected that it leads to hurting others, it went away.
mn19:5.7: When I reflected that it leads to hurting both, it went away.
mn19:5.8: When I reflected that it blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment, it went away.
mn19:5.9: So I gave up, got rid of, and eliminated any sensual thoughts that arose.
mn19:6.1: Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a malicious thought arose …
mn19:6.5: ‘This cruel thought has arisen in me.
mn19:6.6: It leads to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both. It blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment.’
mn19:6.7: When I reflected that it leads to hurting myself …
mn19:6.10: When I reflected that it blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment, it went away.
mn19:6.11: So I gave up, got rid of, and eliminated any cruel thoughts that arose.
mn19:7.1: Whatever a mendicant frequently thinks about and considers becomes their heart’s inclination.
mn19:7.2: If they often think about and consider sensual thoughts, they’ve given up the thought of renunciation to cultivate sensual thought. Their mind inclines to sensual thoughts.
mn19:7.3: If they often think about and consider malicious thoughts … their mind inclines to malicious thoughts.
mn19:7.5: If they often think about and consider cruel thoughts … their mind inclines to cruel thoughts.
mn19:7.6: Suppose it’s the last month of the rainy season, when the crops grow closely together, and a cowherd must take care of the cattle.
mn19:7.7: He’d tap and poke them with his staff on this side and that to keep them in check.
mn19:7.9: For he sees that if they wander into the crops he could be executed, imprisoned, fined, or censured.
mn19:7.10: In the same way, I saw that unskillful qualities have drawbacks, depravity, and corruption, and that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.
mn19:8.1: Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a thought of renunciation arose.
mn19:8.3: ‘This thought of renunciation has arisen in me.
mn19:8.4: It doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. It nourishes wisdom, it’s on the side of freedom from anguish, and it leads to extinguishment.’
mn19:8.5: If I was to keep on thinking and considering like this all night …
mn19:8.7: all night and day, I see no danger that would come from that.
mn19:8.8: Still, thinking and considering for too long would tire my body.
mn19:8.9: And when the body is tired, the mind is stressed.
mn19:8.10: And when the mind is stressed, it’s far from samādhi.
mn19:8.11: So I stilled, settled, unified, and converged my mind internally.
mn19:8.13: So that my mind would not be stressed.
mn19:9.1: Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a thought of love arose …
mn19:9.5: ‘This thought of kindness has arisen in me.
mn19:9.6: It doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. It nourishes wisdom, it’s on the side of freedom from anguish, and it leads to extinguishment.’
mn19:9.7: If I was to keep on thinking and considering like this all night …
mn19:9.9: all night and day, I see no danger that would come from that.
mn19:9.10: Still, thinking and considering for too long would tire my body.
mn19:9.11: And when the body is tired, the mind is stressed.
mn19:9.12: And when the mind is stressed, it’s far from samādhi.
mn19:9.13: So I stilled, settled, unified, and converged my mind internally.
mn19:9.15: So that my mind would not be stressed.
mn19:10.1: Whatever a mendicant frequently thinks about and considers becomes their heart’s inclination.
mn19:10.2: If they often think about and consider thoughts of renunciation, they’ve given up sensual thought to cultivate the thought of renunciation. Their mind inclines to thoughts of renunciation.
mn19:10.3: If they often think about and consider thoughts of love … their mind inclines to thoughts of love.
mn19:10.5: If they often think about and consider thoughts of kindness … their mind inclines to thoughts of cruelty.
mn19:10.6: Suppose it’s the last month of summer, when the crops have been gathered, and a cowherd must take care of the cattle. While at the root of a tree or in the open he need only be mindful that
mn19:10.8: In the same way I needed only to be mindful that
mn19:11.1: My energy was roused up and vigorous, my mindfulness was established and lucid, my body was tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind was unified in samādhi.
mn19:11.2: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn19:11.3: Through the stilling of the movement of the mind, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has internal confidence and unification of mind and consists of rapture and happiness born of stillness.
mn19:11.4: And with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss’.
mn19:11.5: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
mn19:12.1: When my mind had unified in samādhi like this—purified, bright, spotless, rid of taints, pliable, workable, steady, and motionless—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.
mn19:12.2: I recollected many kinds of past lives …
mn19:12.7: This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night.
mn19:12.8: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose;
mn19:12.9: darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
mn19:13.1: When my mind had converged in samādhi like this, I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
mn19:13.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds …
mn19:13.7: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.
mn19:13.8: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose;
mn19:13.9: darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
mn19:14.1: When my mind had converged in samādhi like this, I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
mn19:14.2: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
mn19:14.3: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
mn19:14.4: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire for rebirth, and ignorance.
mn19:14.5: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual life has been lived; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.’
mn19:14.6: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.
mn19:14.7: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose;
mn19:14.8: darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
mn19:15.1: Suppose that in a forested wilderness there was an expanse of low-lying swampland.
mn19:15.2: And a large herd of deer lived nearby.
mn19:15.3: Then along comes a person who wants to harm, injure, and threaten them.
mn19:15.4: They close off the safe, secure path that leads to happiness, and open the wrong path. There they plant domesticated male and female deer as decoys
mn19:15.5: so that, in due course, that herd of deer would meet with tragedy and disaster.
mn19:15.6: Then along comes a person who wants to help keep the herd of deer safe.
mn19:15.7: They open up the safe, secure path that leads to happiness, and close off the wrong path. They get rid of the decoys
mn19:15.8: so that, in due course, that herd of deer would grow, increase, and mature.
mn19:16.1: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
mn19:16.2: And this is what it means.
mn19:16.3: ‘An expanse of low-lying swampland’ is a term for sensual pleasures.
mn19:16.4: ‘A large herd of deer’ is a term for sentient beings.
mn19:16.5: ‘A person who wants to harm, injure, and threaten them’ is a term for Māra the Wicked.
mn19:16.6: ‘The wrong path’ is a term for the wrong eightfold path, that is,
mn19:16.7: wrong view, wrong motivation, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong samādhi.
mn19:16.8: ‘A domesticated male deer’ is a term for desire with relishing.
mn19:16.9: ‘A domesticated female deer’ is a term for ignorance.
mn19:16.10: ‘A person who wants to help keep the herd of deer safe’ is a term for the Realized One, the Perfected One, the fully awakened Buddha.
mn19:16.11: ‘The safe, secure path that leads to happiness’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is:
mn19:16.12: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
mn19:17.1: So, mendicants, I have opened up the safe, secure path to happiness and closed off the wrong path. And I have got rid of the male and female decoys.
mn19:17.2: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do for the benefit of their disciples.
mn19:17.3: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts.
mn19:17.4: Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later!
mn19:17.6: This is my instruction to you.”
mn19:18.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn19:18.2: Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
